main.name: Laura Garrison
main.occupation: Visualization Researcher and Visual Media Designer
main.description: I explore the application of visual media--data visualization, design, illustration--in asking questions and telling stories about complex phenomena
main.bio: I am currently an Associate Professor of Visualization in the Dept. of Informatics at the University of Bergen in Norway, where I investigate the blending of art, science, and technology to ask better questions and share stories about complex phenomena, particularly in the life sciences. In particular, I am interested in exploring how visual rhetorical and narrative approaches can impact, for good or ill, audience comprehension, engagement, emotions, and behavior. I received my PhD in Visualization from the University of Bergen for my work on multiscale visualization of human physiology for discovery and communication. I was awarded the Karl-Heinz Höhne (MedVis) Award in 2021 and the Dirk Bartz Prize this year. Prior to my PhD, I worked as an artist and content director in medical education technology start-ups in Chicago, Silicon Valley, and New York City.

work.title: Visualization researcher
work.description:
My research focused on developing new and more efficient techniques to discover and share physiological data through visualization and data science methods. My goal through this research is to create tools that make this complex information easier to communicate and understand for both scientists and the general public.
Highlights include:
(+) 2nd Prize Karl Heinze Höehne (MedVis) Award, 2021.
(+) Awarded Best Poster at 2019 EuroVis Conference.
(+) Honorable Mention for Best Full Paper VCBM 2021.
(+) Published and presented internationally collaborative research in top visualization journals (IEEE TVCG, CGF, C & G) and conference venues.
(+) Established and participated in international collaborations with researchers across Europe and the US.
(+) Invited speaker to Bio+Med+Vis Spring School 2021 with an international panel of speakers to educate early career medical visualization scientists. 
(+) Supervised student research (1 Master's thesis, 2 Bachelor's projects). 
(+) Administrative and teaching-related duties for UiB's INF 100 (Introduction to Programming), INF 101 (Object-oriented programming), and INF 102 (Algorithms).

work.title: Scientific Technical Director
work.description:
BioDigital is an interactive 3D software platform for visualizing human anatomy, disease, and treatment. Highlights of my time at BioDigital include:

(+) Met with clients and worked with the content and engineering teams to develop scalable interactive 3D experiences that met the clients’ communication needs while supporting the major initiative to grow BioDigital’s internal content library. 
(+) Was part of an interdisciplinary team from academics and industry that was a finalist for the NIH HuBMAP grant. 
(+) Co-presented the BioDigital Human at the 2018 VIZBI Poster session

work.title: Director of Medical Media
work.description:
i-Human Patients, Inc. creates comprehensive simulated patient encounters for medical students and practicing medical professionals that provide unparalleled immersion in the learning environment. i-Human Patient case scenarios help users develop critical clinical skills and diagnostic accuracy while providing an effective tool for educators to evaluate individual and group competencies. Highlights of my time at i-Human include: 
(+) Oversaw creation, acquisition, and management of all media used in i-Human Patient products, including the production of virtual patient avatars and anatomically accurate illustrations. In this role I worked closely with other departments to quickly address media-driven bottlenecks for a diverse set of production deliverables. 
(+) Led the development with a distributed team comprising content specialists, engineers, and outside contractors of a systematically organized media library, incorporating over 4,000 media, including audio, video, illustrations, and radiographs, all with differing viewing requirements. 
(+) Oversaw corporate website, assisted with UI design of flagship products, and created marketing and communication materials for trade shows and conferences. 
(+) Traveled for key trade show and client meetings.

projects.title: Considering Best Practices in Color Palettes for Molecular Visualizations
projects.category: evaluation, visual communication, health literacy, biomedical visualization, molecular visualization
projects.brief: Current color use for molecules in a molecular visualization is largely arbitrary and often chosen based on the client, cultural factors, or personal taste. We explore the rationale for developing guidelines for semantically-meaningful color palettes in molecular visualizations.
projects.pub: Design X Bioinformatics Special Issue of Journal of Integrative Bioinformatics, 2022

projects.title: Trends & Opportunities in Visualization for Physiology: A Multiscale Overview
projects.category: physiology, visual communication, biomedical visualization, health literacy, visual analysis
projects.brief: Combining elements of biology, chemistry, physics, and medicine, the science of human physiology is complex and multifaceted. This report offers a broad and multiscale perspective on key developments and challenges in visualization for physiology according to high-level user task.

projects.title: An Exploration of Practice and Preferences for the Visual Communication of Biomedical Processes
projects.category: evaluation, visual communication, health literacy, biomedical visualization
projects.brief: This study combines techniques in visualization and biomedical illustration to understand the factors that contribute to expert and non-expert preferences for visuals, whether computer-driven or hand-crafted, that describe a given biomedical process.
projects.pub: Proceedings of EuroGraphics Workshop on Visual Computing for Biology and Medicine, 2021

projects.title: SpectraMosaic
projects.category: UI/UX design research, visual data analysis, data science
projects.brief: A tool for interactive visual exploration of magnetic resonance spectroscopy (MRS) data. A single MRS acquisition contains a few dozen metabolites (biochemicals needed to sustain life) that can act as early indicators of pathology, e.g., brain cancer, low oxygen. Our collaborators were spectroscopy experts who wanted a clear visual method to allow them to quickly discover new, possibly interesting, metabolite relations in their data for an individual or for a group of subjects. Developed mainly with p5.js as part of a Master's thesis (Jakub Vašíček).

projects.title: DimLift
projects.category: UI/UX design research, visual data analysis, data science
projects.brief:
Collaborative project with the MedDigit Group at the University of Magdeburg, Germany (first author).
DimLift is a novel design and interaction method using a modified dimensionality reduction technique (iteractive factor analysis of mixed data [FAMD]) for visual exploration of data with many variables. This tool is designed for domain experts to rapidly identify correlated variables via so-called dimensional bundles, and reduce the analysis space. It acts as a supplementary tool to popular analysis tools already in clinical use, such as SPSS.
Developed mainly with D3.js frontend and R/Python backend.
projects.pub: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics, vol. 27, iss. 6, p. 2908–2922, 2021

projects.title: Integrated Dual Analysis of Quantitative and Qualitative High-Dimensional Data
projects.category: UI/UX design research, visual data analysis
projects.brief: Collaborative project with the MedDigit Group at the University of Magdeburg, Germany (second author). Clinical data tend to be quite complex with numerous missing data elements and variables that are continuous (quantitative), free form, and categorical (qualitative). This work explores qualitative descriptive statistics that can be integrated to quantitative statistics for iterative visual exploration of a mixed-type dataset at two levels: item level, and dimension (variable) level. It acts as a supplementary tool to popular analysis tools already in clinical use, such as SPSS. Developed mainly with D3.js frontend and R/Python backend.
projects.pub: IEEE Transactions on Visualization and Computer Graphics, vol. 27, iss. 6, p. 2953–2966, 2021
